Topic.Title: Nvidia slides after downgrade and Intel guidance

Message.Msg: Cloud computing needs lots of processing power and they will need to upgrade over time as well, at least until people somehow fail to make use of ever increasing processing power. Or if they hit an absolute limit on the technology. (something like not being able to shrink past the atomic level + Design issues) Then there could be trouble on margins at that point. A processor is needed for each device that is receiving/sending data. Like phones and tablets. How often do people swap to a new phone or tablet. Its quite a bit more than PCs right? I don't see Nvidia or Intel going anywhere unless ARM manages to kill Intel somehow. Which I highly doubt since Intel can always make one of their own or buy some company. Or a major new tech comes out that kills semi's.

Topic.Title: htc one x+ specs: tegra3?

Message.Msg: This is the final version model (production model). HTC One X specs: General: 2G Network GSM 850 / 900 / 1800 / 1900 3G Network: HSDPA 850 / 900 / 1900 / 2100 Announced: 2012, February Status: Available. Released 2012, May Features: OS Android OS, v4.0 (Ice Cream Sandwich), upgradable to v4.1 Chipset: Nvidia Tegra 3 CPU: Quad-core 1.5 GHz GPU: ULP GeForce Clearly, the HTC One X smartphone is targeting T-Mobile USA. If you look at the HTC One X specs you can see that it supports GSM (2G), HSDPA (3G) but not 4G. The reason why HTC One X is not supporting LTE is because T-Mobile currently does not have LTE (4G) network running and it will only be available in late 2013. T-Mobile mainly uses GSM (2G) network on 900 MHz band in Europe and in U.S. T-Mobile runs GSM on 1900 MHz band. For HSPDA (3G), T-Mobile runs on 1700 MHz and 2100 MHz bands.

It turned out the technology didn’t work at all. We raised all this money. We hired 100 people. We built the technology and it just didn’t work." Now granted, the history of nvidia doesn't inspire a lot of investor confidence, -- and it's not nearly as enduring as Colonel Sanders' secret recipe of 11 herbs and spices -- but "it is what it is", right boys? "When Nvidia was founded, we rapidly almost went out of business." "We built the technology and it just didn’t work." . .

Message.Title: Chinese iPhone 5 knockoff uses Tegra 3
Message.Msg: Memo to Samsung (005930): Now this is how you get away with copying Apple (AAPL)! GizChina reports that a Chinese manufacturer has used leaked photos of Apple’s next-generation iPhone to slap together a quick knockoff of the device called the Goophone I5 and release it before Apple has a chance to launch the genuine article later this month. What’s more, the company has actually patented the knockoff design in China and is poised to sue Apple if it launches the next-generation iPhone in China later this year. For any Chinese readers who are interested in buying a not-quite-iPhone, GizChina says that the Goophone will feature “a Nvidia Tegra 3 quad-core 1.4Ghz CPU, 1GB RAM, Android 4.0 ICS with an iOS 6 theme, 8 megapixel rear camera and a 4-inch screen with an impressive retina display resolution of 1280 x 720.”

Topic.Title: htc one x+ specs: tegra3?

Message.Msg: You are missing my point. My point is that the target (T-Mobile) will not have FD-LTE (4G) network anytime soon (late next year). HTC One X+, just like its processor, still targets T-Mobile regardless. Wouldn’t you think the 2nd generation HTC One X+ would also be serving its existing customers? As stated in this article that HTC One X+ is specifically built for T-Mobile: [“We’ve heard on-and-off rumours of the highly-anticipated HTC One X+ for months now, but it seems that product is going to be announced in the very near future. Designed for AWS networks such as T-Mobile, Mobilicity and Wind Mobile, HTC’s One X+ will, according to reliable XDA Developer source Football, sport a 1.6Ghz quad-core Nvidia Tegra 3 Plus chip, with 1GB RAM, 32GB internal storage, 8MP camera, 42Mbps HSPA+ baseband and the same 1800mAh battery that exists in the current version.”] –mobilesyrub

Topic.Title: htc one x+ specs: tegra3?

Message.Msg: Typo: HTC One X+, just like its predecessor, still targets T-Mobile regardless. Anyway, it would be ludicrous to believe that HTC One X+ would include functionality (i.e. LTE) that cannot be tested on its target carrier’s network. In summary, HTC One X+ does not have T-Mobile LTE specs, neither does T-Mobile.

Message.Title: Why some analysts are wrong. The PC mkt equation on nvidia
Message.Msg: Yes PC sales are slowing. But PC gaming is actually growing! Go google search. You have nvidia and AMD competing in this segment. But nvidia has the cash to innovate. AMD doesn't. Which explains why Kepler is stealing mkt share from AMD. This will likely worsen going forward. What happens when nvidia is in near monopoly?

Topic.Title: Nvidia slides after downgrade and Intel guidance

Message.Msg: Well, for the cloud computing , it may need a lot of devices on the receiving sites, but it definitely not GPU or CPU, It just like the main frame of IBM in 1975, it does not need a lot of CPU or GPUs for the single mainframe which distribute data to the users, and that is why Intel and nvidia, AMD will dies slowly, and Intel's warning proved my point. For the cloud computing, it needs a software compression and decompression software for wireless transmission of wirless video where the bandwidth is very expensive . Intel slowdown, but Apple is booming, it told me that the slowdown of Intel is just because people shifted from PCs to Tablets, and I remember Apple bought an IC fabless company many years ago called PA semiconductor which designed the CPU for handheld devices and founded by DEC employee, well, if all the IPAD used internal designed CPU , and most consumers shift to IPAD, well, of course INTEL will die

INTC, AMD, NVDA, DELL, HPQ will die, while GOOG, AMAZ, MSFT AAPL...will survive, and many new companies offer the cloud service by providing the computing service, application based software service will prosper.

Message.Title: New Video Coding Standard H.265 will Greatly Benefit TegraX Tablets/Smartphones
Message.Msg: With the introduction of H.265 HEVC standard with 2X the compression of H.264 and a 67% improvement in streaming Nvidia TegraX will have the opportunity to gain significant market shares (imo). The new HEVC standard is specifically designed to support ULTRA HDTV at resolution of 4320p (33M-pixel). Instead of macroblocks, HEVC divides the picture into coding tree blocks. Because of the enormous amount of pixels that are presence (33M-pixel at 120 frames/sec) a 1-hour streaming will require 1-TB data for its transmission at "100 mb/s". So, the H.265 which has been specifically designed to accommodate HEVC ULTRA HD will actually consume enormous bandwidth and CPU power specifically on parallel processing. It will require quad-processors or better and a robust GPU to handle large amount of parallel decoding almost full time which is well suited for TegraX type processors for tablets and smartphones.

Topic.Title: Nvidia slides after downgrade and Intel guidance

Message.Msg: Cloud computing is already here. What remains is "Who will power the cloud?". Someone needs to make the processors that provide the proceeding power. INTC and NVDA are among the beneficiaries of that war. There are also reasons to not be connected to the internet all the time anyway due to power consumption from an online connection. Until PHOTO REALISTIC RENDERING is done on the cheap. They have little to worry about... I predict that until real-time interactive movies, with variations in them from AI that allow slightly different experiences every time come out, HIGH MARGIN TECH shall continue to be sold. Also on a side note, I predict that some time in the next 40 years, this tech allows robots to ruin our current economic system by flooding it with cheap and relatively intelligent robot labor.

Topic.Title: New Video Coding Standard H.265 will Greatly Benefit TegraX Tablets/Smartphones

Message.Msg: . nvidia's already badly memory bandwidth constrained processors will be even more constrained with 1-TB of data struggling to get through at HDTV resolutions. But there IS a solution for nvidia's fundamental engineering problem, boys. Rambus designed XDR or XDR2 Mobile Memory. THE fastest memory on the planet, don't u know. By a mile. "The Rambus XDR™2 memory architecture is the world's fastest memory system capable of providing more than twice the peak bandwidth per device when compared to a GDDR5-based system. Further, the XDR 2 memory architecture delivers this performance at 30% lower power than GDDR5 at equivalent bandwidth." Which is why Samsung has used it for years in their HDTV applications. Heck, Samsung liked it so much they bought $100 million of stock in Rambus. And Sony has used it for years in their PlayStation gaming consoles. And Advancing Micro Devices uses it in their lightning-fast high-end graphics cards. Handily beating the pants off of nvidia's best. And with Jen finally paying for a Rambus license too, they might as well use it, right? 'Cause their best competitors already do. .
